Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: The course covered some fundamental mechanisms of cell biology, such as nuclear import and export, protein production and transport, and cell development and proliferation. We also discussed basic membrane physiology, cytoskeletal properties and composition, and transport. Only three scientific papers were assigned for readings over the course of the semester.
This course does a good job of introducing students to biological laboratory techniques and how to interpret data extracted from these experiments.
This course was a good introduction to basic cellular processes. The focus is mainly on understanding concepts and applying these concepts to new situations.
Learned biology
some processes in cell bio
The class covers cell biology & the major processes cells undergo. The material built off  of BIO101.
I learned the basics of the cell cycle, different techniques in which to view cells (fluorescence, GFP tagging, etc.) and I now have a strong understanding of how things move within a cell.
I learned more about biology and different experimental methods that can be used in a laboratory.

I learned the basics of cell biology, such as organelle functions, cell signaling, and methods used to study these processes. It familiarized me with certain ways to organize biological data, such as flow cytometry histograms.
I learned about a lot of the pathways that drive biology on a cellular level and how to study and understand those insights through a combination of lectures, reading and modeling/drawing.
basic cell bio knowledge, better understanding of pathways and how complicated/organized our bodies are in carrying them out
I developed some extremely cool knowledge that allows me to actually understand current cellular biology studies.

Learned a lot of information about the cell. Specifically, I learned about cellular organization, cellular communication, structure, and function. In addition, I learned about several techniques that are used by biologists to investigate cells and how to analyze/interpret the results of relevant experiments.
Learned about secretory pathway, organelles (kind of, but not really), cell cycle, signaling, cell adhesions, and some methods.
Cell Bio gave me a great sense of what biology is like in the real world.  Being that cells are the building blocks of life, it gave a great insight into biological research and methods.
I learned a lot about cell bio and the methods in the field.
I gained some knowledge into cellular biology, including specific pathways that I had not heard of before. I also got to review some biology I learned in high school and understand it better.
I learned about cell biology and how signals are passed through and amplified in a cell. I learned to think critically about how one change in a signaling pathway can lead to a variety of issues.
From this course, I gained a clearer understanding of the structure and function of cells, often in relation to our understandings of ourselves.

This class was actually way more interesting than I thought it would be. Basically, whenever in AP Bio or high school bio they mention cell processes in the vague and abstract, there is a real cellular mechanism for that, and that's what this course teaches. Specific signaling pathways and all of the downstream enzymes that act in it, ribosome localization to the ER, etc. It was very cool.

You learn about a number of molecular pathways (basically memorization) like nuclear import, cotranslational translocation, and vesicle formation. You also learn about cellular structures like mictrotubule formation and the functions of the various organelles.

- General reasoning skills that you might apply to laboratory settings/ experimental design
- New bio specific content
The course focuses on the principals of cell biology. More specifically, cell replication and protein synthesis.

I learned about complex biological mechanisms, including all of the essential molecules and organelles. Most importantly, we discussed scenarios in which such mechanisms go awry - abnormal biology. We, hence, considered real life laboratory techniques for analyzing mutant and wild strains and for tracking the progress of mechanisms.
Learned the basics of cell bio topics like division, signalling, movement, etc.
I learned about the cell and inner processes.
I learned about some specific pathways in the cell, as well as how they are studied.
I learned how cells worked and the processes that distinct parts of the cell carry out.
I learned a basic knowledge of the biology of the cell.
My foundation in cell biology was reinforced.
I learned about a variety of cell biology principles and laboratory procedures
I learned a lot about the nature of cells and how they function.
How to think about cell biology dynamically
I developed a good understanding of basic cell biology and practiced good problem solving skills.
I developed skills in understanding how biological processes occur and analyzing data from experimental results from various laboratory methods.
Biology research techniques

I learned a ton about cell biology (obviously). However, more importantly, I also learned about various lab techniques and how certain results implied certain things going on in the cell (this part of the class was really cool).

a pretty thorough introduction to cell biology! interesting material involving various biological pathways (signaling, secretory, etc.); wish we had focused more on organelle functions (particularly mitochondria, chloroplasts).

I developed the metal capacity to work through complicated diagrams and understand elaborate biological processes. I learned to quickly analyze complex images and take simple ideas to build into more complex ones.
Reading research papers, expansive knowledge about cell biology, note taking skills, critical thinking
Was able to expand my knowledge about microbiologynand cell processes.
A comprehensive introduction to cell biology.
A lot of skill about cellular systems
In depth explanation of topics breezed over in AP Bio - MAP pathway, cotranslational translation, nuclear import, junctions, vesicle fusion
I learned how to applicate some knowledge that I learned to real world scenarios. I also simply memorized many pathways.
Cell biology skills and memorization.
I gained a lot of knowledge about cell biology during this course and the techniques needed to discover those ideas.
I refreshed my biology knowledge and gained a new perspective in the finer details of the cell life process.

The knowledge and skills was quite focused-- rather than an overarching cell bio class (impossible in 6 or so weeks) we instead worked on membranes, and extrapolated that to the nucleus, ER, transport mechanisms, and a bit on the cytoskeleton. We learned about GTPases, protein production, and signal transduction as well, and attempted to apply those to a few real-world examples.

This course was very useful in increasing my knowledge on many of the pathways that occur within the scope of cell biology. Additionally, the course taught me just how important important many of the proteins are and how to analyze the effects when a pat of the pathway may be inhibited or altered.
I learned how to apply what I've learned to new settings and contexts. I've also learned a lot more about the techniques used in real life.

This course taught about cell biology in depth, covering protein production, signaling pathways, cell development, and cell movement. Even if you have taken AP Bio or equivalents before, you will find yourself learning about many processes more in depth.
I learned about cell biology and the way that a cell works.
I developed skills in cell observation techniques and also insight as to cellular structures and processes.
I gained critical thinking skills and understood how to evaluate different processes and biological cycles.
I developed many skills about the biology of the cell in this course. This will be very helpful for me as I am a pre-med student.
I learned the inner workings of the cells at a very broad and simplified scale. I also learned how to study and learn the material primarily on my own and other classmates.
I learned about cells and how to conduct various experiments. Experimental thinking.
learned some basics of cell bio, plus some detailed steps of various cellular processes
Learned a lot of cell biology. I loved the class.
I learned how to think critically, however there was a lot of memorization.
I learned more about the processes that help cells function. I also learned the difference between sufficiency and necessity, and some of the experimental procedures used to study cells.
By taking this course, I developed the necessary skills to proceed to the next courses of the bio sequence
Time management, note taking, group collaboration

I saw growth in my ability to approach problems that required application of knowledge. This class was very insightful for cells which form the foundation of many forms of life. These facts help provide insights to things such as disease stemming from mutation and malfunction that was very interesting.
This class teaches the basics of cell biology incorporating a multitude of cellular pathways.
In this course I learned more about specific research methods in biology and cells in more detail than I ever did in high school.
I learned about the cell, and its inner workings in a broad but comprehensive way. I feel like I got enough detail and depth without dedicating too much time to any one aspect or process of the cell.
Molecular cellular pathways including but not limited to transport complexes, cell composition, vesicle formation, cell cycle, signaling mechanisms, etc.
I developed the knowledge, skills, and insights relevant for cell biology and specifically with the specifics of the inter-working of the organelles and skeleton of a cell.

I gained more knowledge into the processes that occur within a cell, as well as some of the history of biological discoveries and advancements. I also learned many new experimental procedures, which was quite interesting. One skill I gained was writing concise and accurate answers to questions, due to the limit to the amount we were allowed to write.

This course really helps you to approach biology in a very practical sense, specifically through a laboratory or experimental lens. Professor Horsley not only teaches you the basics about cell biology, but also explains how such lessons were discovered in the lab. I learned a lot about different experimental techniques and how they may be used to understand different parts of the cell and its processes.
I learned about cell biology and focused a lot on mutations and pathways and all the things that could do wrong at the subcellular level.
Basic biology.
I gained a general understanding of cellular processes.

This course was structured like a middle or high school course, which is not a compliment. Discussions of fundamental topics were repetitive and superficial, encouraging a basic memorization of the steps in a process or pathway rather than a full understanding of the specific role that each individual step has in the overall procedure, nor even the slightest intuition behind the development or advantages of this fragmentation of a process into numerous small steps. Lectures were never designed for the proper 75 minute period, some ending 20 minutes early, others ending without having covered 10 or more slides of content. Illustrations on the board were hopeless in the enormous lecture hall, being practically invisible from the back of the hall, not that they were that useful to begin with given that the lecture slides usually demonstrated the same material more clearly. Lecture slides were expected to be printed prior to class each day, as with the other intro biology courses (BIOL 101104), but these slides would sometimes not be uploaded to Canvas until 8pm the night before, making this difficult, as well as expensive. The textbook is not available in a bound form online from a reliable retailer, so the only option is the Yale Bookstore edition (contains only a few selected chapters from the full text), which is both significantly more expensive than the loose-leaf  version which includes the entire text and was not available by mid-semester, when BIOL 102 begins; the Yale Bookstore version also literally has a typo on the cover ("Cell and Moleculuar Biology"). The pre-class quizzes on Canvas are useless because they quiz on minutia from the readings (easily answered on Wikipedia or a Google Search) before having covered the content in class; it would be much more helpful and informative as to one's personal understanding of the material if a quiz covering key concepts were offered after the lecture.

Strengths: going over lab techniques and how to interpret data from them, gaining a basic understanding of cellular biology processes, discussion section activities are definitely worth your time, and the homework properly prepares you for the exams
Weaknesses: The professor!!

Discussion sections are a great strength of this course because we worked through problems that helped focus and reinforce our learning. The readings are extremely dense and can be difficult to grasp before having attended lecture. The lectures can also be difficult to follow at times.
The slides are a good system; however, the professor for 102 was not good.

this course was so bad. the discussion sections were not helpful in facilitating learning. the lectures were so poorly executed. the material is dry and not at all presented in a way that would be of any interest to anyone.

The way that the content was organized was helpful and the order we learned topics made sense, however the lecture slides were hard to follow after lecture. They made sense during the lecture, but when I would go back to go over them I would often have a hard time following them. The lecture slides were organized much better in 101.
I believe how the course is taught is effective for learning the material.

I definitely liked this course more than biology 101 because we could ask questions more frequently and Professor Horsley went back over the information that we were confused on and made sure we understood it. 

I think a strength of this course was the real-life demonstrations of cellular processes/movements and that a weakness is that the slides weren't always in an order that made sense, with some topics having slides that were separated from each other throughout the powerpoint.
The course really teaches the material well, especially with the TA's and discussion sections. the lecturer could improve by making better slides to take notes from.

The course material is intrinsically interesting. It's very accessible as it's not too complicated, and it's cool to get to know some of the basics of how life operates. The expectations of what students should know on homework and the exams is clear and reasonable. However, it does involve a lot of memorization, sections can be slow without a good TF, and the quality of teaching wasn't as good as 101.

I think that the textbook readings for the course go through the information at a much higher level than we learn about in class and so it seems almost pointless to put the time and effort in to read the 40+ pages of textbook reading and struggle to understand it if we are going to talk abut what exactly we need to know the next day in class.

loved the activities during class, loved drawing on the board (next time, pls do that the whole semester and not just the second half), liked the demonstrations bc they helped my visualize and i remembered hand motions a lot during the final exam

wording on hws and tests left a lot to be desired...felt like questions were often unclear

multiple contradictions between slides and study guides, multiple mistakes on slides...made already dense material very confusing. i get that mistakes happen but it seems like the slides should be prepared well
I thought it was a very well-structured course.

The class is poorly organized, Professor Horsley does not prepare for lecture at all, and her main method of simplifying concepts is to simply leave out crucial information. She tends to contradict herself between sentences, confusing the class. Bring binoculars to have any hope of seeing the diagrams she draws on the board.

The test questions are fair and relatively straightforward. The on stage performances of the instructors were interesting and helped to clarify the materials taught in the class. The pace of the class is just right and the pre-class quizzes encourages the students to preview materials taught in class and helps students grasp the concepts better.

Strengths: study guides were very clear, much of the course material was interesting, and faculty clearly were knowledgeable about cellular biology.
Weaknesses: in some cases, it seemed that extra information was provided, although this wasn't always noted to be as such. Also, would have enjoyed seeing some more relevant real-life examples of how the cellular-level concepts could influence the bigger picture.

Assigned readings do not line up with course material. The assigned readings go into far more detail than is needed. Also, papers that are assigned reading are hardly discussed in class or section; further, they are not annotated and are therefore pointless to assign to Bio 102 students unless the paper is discussed and explained.
This course has SO MUCH information and things can easily be mixed up with each other.  It would be helpful if what was taught in enrichment was how lectures were taught.
Lecture wasnt very important, everything you needed was on the slides and even when I wanted to write things down it was already there on the slide.

The class was good in that it covered a lot of laboratory techniques that are essential to research. The pre-class quizzes should be more relevant to the class material. The quizzes went too in-depth into information we didn't even cover in class or was tested on. In addition, there should be article annotations for the articles we read, because they were a little in depth. Finally, the textbook should have been the same as the the one used in BIOL 101 in order to save everyone some hassle (and money).

The course was very interesting because I really enjoyed learning about the different signaling pathways and the cell cycle. One suggestion is to provide a study guide for the midterm exam just so students can have an idea about how the test is formatted.
The course would likely benefit from more interactive and engaging lectures as well as more clarity in expectations for assignments and content.

The weakness is that lecture is often disorganized and kind of dry. The strengths are the pre-lecture quizzes keeping you engaged with the material, and honestly, I liked that there was a midterm even though it was a half-semester class because it allowed me to review the material and get a sense of how well I understood it so I wasn't completely blind-sided by the final.

The mechanisms were relatively easy to memorize and understand, and once you understood them the exams were quite simple. The most annoying part of the course was the expectation of us to understand lab techniques when some students had never actually performed such experiments by hand.

Lectures weren't always cohesive/ there were many irrelevant or poorly explained slides. The 'challenge the class' parts of the lecture weren't helpful to me personally, and some of them were just irrelevant to the course work. For example, while I do think it's important to consider how unethical the widespread use of HeLa cells is, I don't think 3 minutes of small talk with the people we sit next to is really going to generate any novel discussion or recourse for these sorts of problems.

I felt that it was difficult to understand what material was going to be tested and what was extraneous. It was also very difficult to see the larger picture of the processes being taught. For example, it was only after three lectures that I understood that the past lectures had all been conjoined by the common theme of protein transport/ creation.

The course was not well structured. I always felt bombarded with information in lectures and I could never tell what was significant to take away from the course. The information that we learned also felt randomly specific instead of more general and relevant information pertaining to cell biology.

The powerpoints and study guides were extremely helpful, and the instructor Professor Horsely herself was very animated. I wish there was more student-professor interaction during the class, though, or student-student. I would have enjoyed being challenged more often during the class to engage with my classmates. Also, the pre-class quizzes were a good idea, but I did not find it helpful to read large portions of the dense textbook. Most students I spoke with did not bother with the reading, and it felt like a waste of a purchase. The quizzes could be done without the book. An pre-class quiz in class would have been more effective. Discussion section was very helpful and had structure to it. The TA clarified what was previously taught in class.

The main weakness was that the topics seemed kind of unstructured. I'm not sure if that is a flaw of the course or just something inherent to the topics, but it was difficult to link the topics together. Rather than feeling like a systematic exploration of cell bio, it kind of seemed like a handful of processes tossed together and that made it somewhat difficult at the final.

Strengths: Professor Hoarsely cares about the course and the students; course work is not too heavy; lecture is interesting. 

Cons: Lectures cover more simple ideas than testing requires

It's an intro course. Broad overview with little depth--I think they covered what needs to be covered with a survey course but no more. Perhaps they could have made the material more intriguing somehow, but I'm not sure.
I think that there could be more practice problems that are like what we see on exams.
The lectures were not very interactive.

The course material was very interesting, however it could have been presented in a clearer manner. I also wish there was more of a focus on understanding the material, not memorizing the exact wording from the lectures.
Lectures can be improved to include only relevant information.
The strengths of this course are that it was well-organized and was taught by a team of knowledgeable professors.
I thoroughly enjoyed the course and have no complaints
I think section could be made a lot more useful, also that concepts could be tied together during lecture instead of just learning more and more information
The course did a good job with using study guides and section to prepare us for the exam. The lectures were also really helpful. The readings at times felt unrelated or unnecessarily long.
The lecturer was confusing at points, even saying Wait, Im confused while attempting to teach. Not a great impression to leave on a group of intro bio students.
Strengths of this course include the professor's enthusiasm and various learning activities (chalk board, videos, partner discussion, etc). Weaknesses include inconsistent timing of lectures.

I thought the class was fine as is. Because it's a big lecture course, there's no getting around hosting a lecture, so this can't be rectified. I'm not a huge fan of lectures, but I can't really call that a flaw of the course.

The lectures are not very attention-grabbing and sometimes the information is communicated in confusing ways. Because of this, it can be difficult to engage with the material during class. However, it is always clearthrough the weekly study guides what information students are responsible for knowing.
a strength of this course was providing enrichment sessions, which were extremely helpful.
a strongly taught course overall; wish that there was more emphasis on experimental design and understanding the nuances of various techniques and assays.

The strengths include the many outlets of aid that the course provides with teaching fellows, student-run discussion sections, and peer tutoring. I wish the power point slides would include more information.

Strength: The take home quizzes take some pressure off students, which is good
Weakness: I think all the information necessary for the tests and course should be present on the slides.
The lectures were slightly disorganized but the sections were helpful in clarifying topics.

The lectures are a weakness. I didn't really feel like I was able to learn a lot while I was there. I felt like the pre-lecture quizzes were helpful either. I liked the homework sets but wished they more closely matched the exams.
I thought the professor struggled a lot to clarify concepts and I felt that her attempts wasted time.
Lectures were sometimes not great at presenting the material in a absorbable manner.
Hard to stay involved while so much going on
lectures werent super engaging, not sure the knowledge i gained will last beyond the courses end, just a lot of memorization

strengths: Prof. Horsley's teaching style - small group discussions, skits with the TAs, multiple opportunities to ask questions, easy problem sets
weaknesses: the online quiz before every class meeting takes 5-10 minutes but only asks a few questions about a long reading, size (>200 students)

I think the biggest strength of this class is the sections. I learned more in the one 50 minute section than I did for the two 75 minute lectures every weak. I found that lecture could sometimes be very confusing and I would need my TA to clarify many concepts.
The lectures could be more straightforward.

The weaknesses of this course included some poor explanations on certain topics that led to class confusion about concepts that ended up on the final exam. When there is confusion regarding a concept, especially when incorrect information is taught in lecture (the effect of phospholipid tail length on membrane fluidity is the first that comes to mind), there needs to be a class-wide correction made during lecture and not just a follow up post on Piazza.

Some strengths are that a lot of material is presented in the course and all the concepts tested on the tests reflect the material presented in lecture. The material itself is very interesting, and the homework and discussion sections do a good job reviewing those ideas.

Prof. Park really made this course for me. She was professional, helpful, and kind during every interaction. A weakness may be the number of retractions of the lecture slides. This was very different from BIOL 101 with Prof. Koelle.

While this course is hindered by its length, it does a great job with depth, and I know how its specific topics work. I also appreciate professor Horsley's attempts to appeal to many types of learners-- through physical, video, and textual examples, she put a great deal of care into making all feel welcome (and while not every example worked on me, I'm sure they did for some).

A strength and weakness was the class time-- unlike BIOL101, the timing was more variable, which meant that sometimes lectures finished early and sometimes they spilled into the next. This is a strength because unlike BIOL101, we were not held to ask questions for the remainder-- when we finished early we generally got to leave early, and when lectures spilled over Professor Horsley made sure we understood everything, especially problematic topics that were hard to explain.

However, sometimes the lecture was unclear (and even once or twice wrong), so a weakness was needing to go on google or Piazza and find out the answer to some unclear questions on our own. To Professor Horsley's credit, if she made a mistake she rectified it in the lecture slides. 

Finally, the readings were assigned prior to lecture. This allowed us to understand lecture better, but as we were only responsible for the reading covered in the lecture and the textbook is particularly advanced, I found myself memorizing difficult concepts that would never be tested, a problem that I never had in BIOL101. This led to often working much harder than I should.
I liked the way the discussion sections were ran, I felt like I learned a lot. Lectures were very dull.
There are a lot of resources to help students succeed.

While Professor Horsley does a good job in incorporating many different activities, it does seem like the course could be organized better. Some concepts are given too much time in lecture, while other important ones arent covered in depth. The slides are helpful, but could be better arranged; the summary slide of each concept is a lot less helpful after an entire chunk of lecture has already been spent explaining the concept.
The professor drew too many diagrams on the board and we couldnt see them. Grading was quite arbitrary.
Strengths of the course include and engaging professor, but weakness lie in the clarity of the slides; I felt as though the slides could have been more succinct and specific.

The strengths of this course was the lecturer, who was very adept at explaining the different cycles, but the weaknesses included the slides, which were slightly unclear. The slides could have been made to be more concise at representing information.

The pre-class quizzes on Canvas were not effective at all. Even if I were to take notes and do the readings on the topic, I wasn't able to fully understand the questions being asked on the quizzes or know the right answer until after lecture. I didn't think it made sense to take a quiz on information that I wouldn't be given a lecture on until the following day. The BIOL 101 format where we took one quiz a week on info we learned the two lectures prior was much more effective. There was too much of a chance to get a low grade with only 5 points on the canvas quizzes. I didn't learn anything from them.
I appreciated the different types of methods used for teaching information, however the course could be significantly improved by the organization of the lectures themselves.

Strengths-- very structured, really liked the lecture slides/study guides
How it could be improved-- sometimes the readings were very long and not always about the material on the slides, which encourages people not to do them
Readings are dense and complicated and somewhat unrelated to what is discussed in lecture. Requires a lot of rote memorization
More engaging leactures
This course could be improved by explaining the things more detailed since there was a lot of confusion.  also think there should have been more information on the slides.

This course could be improved by connecting concepts together better. It just felt like we were receiving information without much context on why things were important or how they related to each other. Because of this, the lectures took concerted effort to pay attention to. Better slide and lecture organization could improve how students mentally sort the course material.

Homework was too easy. I didn't feel that my knowledge was deepened by doing the assignments, which felt too simple to be preparing me for real scientific pursuits.

The textbook readings did not feel worthwhile. They were too long, and they provided a lot of information that felt superfluous because it was never brought up in lecture or tests. After a few attempts at getting through the readings, I usually just opened up the quizzes and looked through the textbook to try to find the answers.

Discussion sections were better than lecture. The material was presented in a more engaging way, and I had fun working through the material with my peers. They could be improved by going through information slower or decreasing the amount covered in a given section.

This course does a really good job of giving a lot of information in very little time, however, this makes the class much more difficult and frustrating than it needs to be.  It could be improved by covering a little less and spending more time on the material rather than giving a lot of very specific examples that are barely talked about in lecture.

Strengths- well organized, helpful sections, enrichment
Weaknesses- misinformation by professor during lecture
More organized slides would be appreciated, sometimes they contained unnecessary information
The content was difficult, but organized into lectures well. Having the textbook was also very helpful. I think that it could be improved in how information was presented to the class.
The variety of activities involved in the course was useful, as well as the discussion sections. However, I didn't think the preclass quizzes were helpful at all.
The discussion sections really helped my understanding.

The readings assigned were way too dense and highly inefficient (and the text itself was not very to-the-point, compared to Campbell textbooks); basically the number of pages assigned per 2 days would take forever to read if actually done diligently with frequent note-taking. Lecture and discussion were far more efficient as we probably covered 75% of the material that the readings did in wayyy less time (the readings just took way, way too long and I gave up doing them at all in the end). In the end the most efficient learning method turned out to be to skip the readings and rely mainly on lecture and discussion coverage, then possibly skim the readings for missed details. Offer more than one review session; there was only one review session based on majority vote so many of us could not attend it due to mandatory events that were scheduled months in advance.

The greatest strength was honestly was Professor Park. I have heard from multiple peers not only my own that she was very attentive and explained very thoroughly concepts that were confusing in the lecture class during her enrichment sessions and she was always available for help. The discussion sections were also wonderful and help greatly in covering the material of the course. The greatest weakness was the lecture time. I feel that the way the lecture was taught was very problematic and confusing to keep up with and did not flow as smoothly as when material was covered in Biology 101.

The quality of the discussion section could have been improved. I believe they could have been much more helpful had the review slides presented been distributed or if more time was spent discussing each topic to ensure complete understanding. Also, the lecture seemed only to convey the most basic information. Students occasionally asked questions that did not receive satisfactory answers, in my opinion.

Professor Horsley makes it clear that the focus of the course is experimental. Therefore, the midterm and final exams as well as the homework are very data-driven and focus on interpretation and application. I think this course's TA's as well as Professor Horsely do a great job in presenting the material in a way that we may easily understand it in a more experimental lens.

One weakness of this course is that it is a bit unorganized. We were required to print the lecture slides each class, but the slides are mostly just photos. The powerpoint slides used in lecture were not very useful and sometimes the lectures felt a bit skewed.
The enrichment course was most helpful.
Needs more one on one stuff, the section was just a rehash of the lecture. Could be taught much clearer if the slides were in order and matched the distributed ones.

The intro bio sequence as a whole is weak in that there is a wide variety of preparation among the students. As it is near impossible to test out of intro bio even having taken a solid AP bio course, the people in the class range from people who have barely taken high school bio to people who have a strong biology background. Thus, in lecture, the professors aim to simplify information so that anyone can follow along, causing it to be long/boring for experienced students to sit through. However, on problem sets and tests, the standard of knowledge required is way more than was taught. Thus, the level of instruction is quite different from the level of knowledge expected.

No, this course is neither particularly informative nor intellectually stimulating; despite the fascinating content, this course manages to quash all enthusiasm for the material with repetitive and uninteresting lectures, overly simplified and superficial descriptions and explanations, time-consuming and largely unhelpful demonstrations, and monotonous weekly homework and quizzes. The only reason you should take this course is if the BIOL 101104 sequence is a requirement for you or if you really want to take BIOL 104 because you've heard it's amazing (I'm in the latter category.)
I would not recommend this course to another student. The material was not taught and the homework was disproportionally easy compared to tests.
If the professor were different, yes. The content is interesting and I enjoyed working through experimental evidence to interpret the results.
Sure

I would only recommend this course if they also enroll in Julie Park's enrichment session. I would not have done as well I have done in this class if I had not enrolled to be a part of Julie Park's enrichment session. The class overall is very dull, but I guess that's expected for a introductory lecture class. I was very often confused during lecture because Professor Horsley was not the best at explaining concepts. I would advise anyone who takes this class who has not had any advanced biology experience to be conscious of how much self-studying they will have to do outside of class.
if you are taking this class, it's probably because you have to, so just take it and get it over with.
Since this course is a prerequisite for many majors, I would recommend people take this course, but in comparison to 101 i would say the overall course is less quality.

I found the material very interesting & would recommend this course to someone who is interested in STEM. The course is not easy & most people taking it are for their major, but it is still enjoyable learning!

If the other student was interested in biology/medical work then yes, I'd recommend it to them. But if they don't have any interest then they'd probably hate the class, so I wouldn't recommend it in that case.
I would recommend this course to another student because this course teaches a lot of the needed material for laboratory work and future biology majors.
Yes, I think it would be a great science credit for anyone, especially those already interested in biology. Most people take it as a pre-req, but it offers a lot by itself.
I would recommend Biology 102 to another student because it is a necessary part of the bio sequence
i guess, but i would warn them that explanations are often confusing
Yes. This is a must-take course. Probably one of my favorites I've taken thus far.
If you are taking this course, you are probably required to, so there's really not much to say here.
Yes, this is an interesting class.

If the student was interested in biology and had not yet been exposed to it, then yes. However, this course seemed to be full of introductory information, so I would not recommend this to someone with knowledge of cells.
Maybe.
This course is interesting, but quite challenging.  If you are a pre-med or looking into doing biological research, this course would be helpful.
Yes, cell bio is cool.

It's a great course if you've already had some exposure to biology research. If you haven't had this kind of exposure, the class might be a little tough and confusing. It's definitely a good course to learn basic biology in.
I would recommend this course to other students because it gives a really good background for cell biology.

The course material is much, much more interesting than BIOL 101. Horsley is not a very interesting lecturer and sometimes gets confused, but the textbook provides a comprehensive overview of everything you need to know (and more) and it's really hard to end up completely lost in this course as long as you go to lecture, do the pre-lecture quizzes, etc.
You have to take it if you're premed.

No. Professor Horsley doesnt even deign to go over the slides before lecture each day, so inconsistencies and errors are commonplace. Learning is primarily dependent on the student, and information is not communicated effectively at all. If possible, avoid.
No, only if they have to take it. I personally did not find the teaching style engaging or the topics that interesting.

Most students will take this course if they have already gone through BIOL101. I would say that this course is not as well structured as Kolle's 101, however it is still possible to learn and understand the large concepts presented in lecture.

I would recommend this course to another student as it is part of the bio sequence and can be a handy pre-requisite class. It is not a very demanding class and the peer tutors are a great help with homework assignments, making the class a breeze if you put some effort in.
I would recommend if needed for a major, but if wanting to learn biology I think there would be more interesting courses.
Yes  if youre interested in pursuing a career in medicine or cellular biology this course is a good introduction.

I would say to only take this course if you have to, as a prereq, or premed, or whatever. There are definitely more interesting courses out there and more applicable ones. This course is designed to provide the students for knowledge that they can use for upper level biology courses.
I would if they wanted more of an understanding about cell biology.
Yes, it is mandatory for pre med students.
Yes. It is a necessary step in ones understanding of the biological sciences.
I would recommend this course to any biology/chemistry major as it contains knowledge that is essential for the major.
Yes, it was fascinating and discussed topics that I would not normally have thought about.
You have to take it, so might as well
Yes, if you are interested in pursuing science in the future this is a good background class to get into it. Not too challenging if you pay attention and go to class.
If you dont need the class for your major, I would definitely suggest selecting a different SC credit.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student as it challenges one to think analytically about biology, and is a great foundation for anyone interested in pursuing biology or a career in medicine.
Absolutely. If you're premed or bio major, you'll have to take this. Some people complain about the bio sequence, but I think it's fine. Don't have any qualms.
If required for ones major or to keep ones academic options open, then I would recommend this course. It is not, however, a course that I would take for fun.
Yes, I would recommend this to another student because it is well structured and makes learning the material easy.
recommend to any pre-medical student, as it is, in fact, a requirement.
I would recommend this course for prospective biology majors. It is important to understand simple concepts in order to learn of more complex ones in biology-related majors.
Yes, I think the intro biology sequence is a necessary starting point for many people who wish to enter into a scientific major or field later on.
Only if this is required for what you want to do.
Yes you have to take it
Yes, gives a very concrete/visual explanation of difficult topics, definitely more comprehensive than the cell bio material in AP Bio
I would only take this class if it was a requirement.
If you need to take it.

I would recommend this course to a student who needs to take it for a major requirement or who just really loves biology. I would not recommend it to someone who is just looking to fill a science credit requirement, because it does require work and is highly specific in the material it teaches.
Anyone interested in biology should take this course. It is basic enough for anyone to jump in, but engaging enough to keep the AP bio kids entertained.

I mean, if you're taking this, it's to get to the next level of biology. The class is a large lecture, and some days are a drag to get through. However, that's exactly how the fundamentals generally are, so it is worth building your basic knowledge. Overall, take the class, get it over with, and move on-- it isn't the fault of Professor Horsley or Park-- it's simply the nature of a prerequisite.
Chances are if youre taking this course its because you have to. If you dont have to there are other science and biology classes which are more interesting and better taught.
Yes, because you learn a lot about cell biology and the workload was not overwhelming.
If necessary, then yes.
Yes, you need it to major in bio.
I would recommend the biology sequence to a friend because the material is interesting.
Yes
Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone who is majoring in science. This course provides the foundations that are required for advanced levels.
I would recommend this course to another student. Biology is probably the most interesting and manageable subjects out of the hard sciences. It is extremely helpful for pre-med.

The topics were interesting, but not taught in the best way. Because it was a pre-requisite I would recommend in order to take other classes, but not for the profound nature of the material of this specific class.
Yes. It is necessary for nearly any stem major, and it is pretty well taught
No, but most people are taking it to fill a requirement anyway
Yes

I would because it still necessary in order to pursue other more specific biology classes. I wouldn't recommend it as a fun class to take since it is unexplained well and thought in an unorganized manner.
I would not recommend this course to another student. I did not feel engaged by the material as presented in lecture, and course work usually felt like a chore.

I wouldn't encourage or discourage another student from taking this course. It is not terrible, but the intro bio sequence is not organized very well in general. I may warn another student about what the class is like and how quickly it moves, but I wouldn't tell them not to take it.
I would recommend this course to another student interested in the biological sciences, but not to someone looking to simple fulfill a science requirement.
I would recommend this course only if you are a prospective STEM major.
Would not recommend for students who do not need biology for their major.
Yes, it is the perfect introductory bio class.
Only if you are premed/it is required. There are far more interesting Science credits for students majoring in something else.
I would recommend it to fulfill prerequisite requirements.
I would recommend this course for those interested in going into the sciences because it gave a very good background for what may be needed to know for the future.

Most people taking the biology sequence are required to by one of the biology majors; I believe that this is a relatively easy class for any of the bio-related majors. If it is not required for your major, I would recommend if you have a strong interest/background in biology.
Yes, this is a good, fun course for those who love science or even for those want to dabble a bit in science.
If you had to take it.
Not really. I mean, it's a requirement, so other students will have no choice but to take it if they are most stem majors, but definitely do not take it for fun.
